data.title: Tusk Or Tooth? From Central Fl Phosphate Pit

data.text:
My father obtained this fossil around 40-50 years ago. He worked at a chemical lab associated with a phosphate mine, and a friend gave him this fossil which had been discovered in one of the mining pits. It has sat in a drawer for nearly all the years since. My father has given it to me and I would like to find out more about what it might be. Any help is welcome. Photos included. The whole piece is about 8 inches long and a little more than 2 inches in diameter. Image 24 shows an odd, shallow man-made hole, unknown origin. Very solid and heavy piece.

Many thanks,

Rod

I've found a range of fossils in my backyard excavation (NW Sarasota, alongside Whitaker Bayou) that look like the generic dugong rib pictures found everywhere. What is it about these bones that made they positively identifiable as dugong? Couldn't any other non-avian creature of appropriate size also leave behind similar or identical bones? I just find it a little hard to believe that all of the fossils are from the same critter.

Sirenian bones have a unique pachyosteosclerotic histology. Pachyostosis is the external inflation of the cortical bone, while osteosclerosis is the shrinking of the medullary cavity. Sirenians have both (hence pachyosteosclerosis), so when you find inflated, super dense ribs like that - they are sirenian. When people use the term dugong, they are not specifically referring to the genus Dugong (which is known in the western Pacific and a single fossil from the Pleistocene of Florida), or the Dugongidae, they are just meaning sea cow in general. It is not really possible to differentiate between the ribs of manatees (Trichechidae) and dugongid sea cows (Dugongidae), but IIRC dugongids are more common in the Miocene of the Atlantic coastal plain. The one exception to that rule is size - very tiny ribs can be identified as Nanosiren, and truly humongous ribs (1+ meter in length) are unique to Dusisiren and Hydrodamalis in the North Pacific.

My apologies to drronin for hijacking this thread.

Thanks for the info RichW9090 and Boesse. I've got to do some thinking and digest what you said. I had noted that the finds obviously looked like rib material but I had some difficulty with the lack of any apparent marrow cavities. As I understand it, fossils do not always retain their inner composition and so I thought the fossils I've found may have just been some other long bone which had lost the inner details. In general then, what you've pointed at is that ribs from other critters are not often found since those critters do not experience the same level of pachyosteosclerosis, thus making them more easily broken down into small unrecognizable fragments. I still find it odd that I've not found more remnants from other types of animals.

There's also an issue with the mix of land and water animal remains I've found. Alongside the supposed dugong ribs I've also found horse/bison teeth, glyptodont scutes, turtle/tortoise bits, bivalves, shark teeth (including a ~4" meg ), possible horse/bison/camel/llama ankle bones, possible deer teeth, and many more. It may just be a byproduct of the manner that the fossils are brought to me, down the bayou, which would jumble up different fossil bed contributions.

Sirenian bones have a unique pachyosteosclerotic histology. Pachyostosis is the external inflation of the cortical bone, while osteosclerosis is the shrinking of the medullary cavity. Sirenians have both (hence pachyosteosclerosis), so when you find inflated, super dense ribs like that - they are sirenian. When people use the term dugong, they are not specifically referring to the genus Dugong (which is known in the western Pacific and a single fossil from the Pleistocene of Florida), or the Dugongidae, they are just meaning sea cow in general. It is not really possible to differentiate between the ribs of manatees (Trichechidae) and dugongid sea cows (Dugongidae), but IIRC dugongids are more common in the Miocene of the Atlantic coastal plain. The one exception to that rule is size - very tiny ribs can be identified as Nanosiren, and truly humongous ribs (1+ meter in length) are unique to Dusisiren and Hydrodamalis in the North Pacific.

In Florida, Trichechus is a Pleistocene taxon (possibly a representative in the Late Pliocene), according to Hulbert. He organizes the taxa like this:

Infraorder SIRENIA (sea cows, manatees, dugongs)

Family PRORASTOMIDAE (Eocene)

Family PROTOSIRENIDAE (Eocene)

Family DUGONGIDAE (dugongs - all Very Late Oligocene to Late Pliocene)

Subfamily HALITHERIINAE

Subfamily DUGONINAE

Family TRICHECHIDAE (manatees - Late Pliocene(?) to Late Pleistocene)

Among the DUGONGIDAE (Subfamily DUGONGINAE) Hulbert mentions an "undescribed genus and species" from the Late Pliocene. In a footnote, he says:

82. The presence of an undescribed late Pliocene dugongid from the Caloosahatchee Formation in Charlotte County was noted by Morgan (1994). When described, it would be the youngest member of the family from the Western Atlantic.

Has this dugongid from the Caloosahatchee been described, Bobby? What is the name?

Edited June 12, 2013 by Harry Pristis
